Kalamazoo, MI 49007
RE: License#: CI390403045
Investigation#: 2 023C0000139
Dear Ms. Thorpe:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. No
substantial violations were found.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at.
Sincerely,
Paul Fatato, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

INVESTIGATION:
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of Staff
Section The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative, supervisory,
Description social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to perform the
prescribed functions required by these administrative rules and in the
agency’s program statement and to provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On January 1, 2023, Youth A went AWOL and while AWOL, Staff 1
followed from a distance. When Staff 1 was following Youth A, Youth A
noticed Staff 1 and ran up to her. When Youth A ran up to Staff 1,
Youth A poured an entire bottle of water on her and then started pulling
Staff 1's hair. Staff 1 attempted to get Youth A's hands out of her hair
and scratched Youth A's arm in the process. Youth A currently has a
scratch on the left-hand side of her neck that travels on to her chest.
Investigation Administrator 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on
1/3/2023. She reported Youth A was back in the home and doing well.
4

She had spoken to the DHHS worker and interviews with Youth A and
staff are scheduled for the end of the week.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on 1/3/2023.
She refused to speak but appeared to be in good health. She presented
verbal aggression towards staff when asked a question.
Administrator 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on
1/9/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported being
informed of the incident later in the day after the incident occurred. She
was told by Staff 1 and Lead Trainer that the two youth went AWOL,
and Staff 1 followed them. The youth split up and Staff 1 followed
Youth A because Youth A is “cognitively impaired” (IQ 65), and they
feared for her safety if not unsupervised. Staff 1 informed her that
Youth A threw a bottle of water at her and then grabbed her hair. This
caused them both to fall to the ground. Administrator 1 was unaware if
Lead Trainer was witness to this incident. She also reported staff
believed Youth A may have been on a substance since her eyes were
dilated, so the EMS was called. She described Staff 1 as the most
professional staff at the facility, who also works in the community and
school systems.
Administrator 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on
1/9/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported Staff 1
works part-time on the overnight shift at the facility. She also reported
Staff 1 has a “long history” of community involvement and has
completed all required trainings include the “six core” training. Staff 1 is
documented to have attended all staff meetings.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on 1/9/2023 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported being present when
Youth A and Youth B put their coats and backpacks on appeared to be
ready to leave the facility. She attempted to de-escalate the situation by
talking to the two youth, but her efforts were unsuccessful. The two
youth had reportedly just returned to the facility prior to Staff 1
beginning her shift. Staff 1 also reported Lead Trainer was present
during their intervention with the youth and was also engaged in the
discussion with the youth. Staff 1 reported the two youth left the facility
and began walking towards the east with her following approximately
100 feet behind. At Cedar Street, the two-youth separated, and Staff 1
continued to follow Youth A because of her limited cognitive ability.
Staff 1 said all at once, Youth A turned and began to swear at Staff 1
before charging towards her. Youth A yelled that she hated Staff 1 and
wanted to “beat my ass”. As Youth A was approaching Staff 1, Staff 1
said she started backing up. Youth A stopped approaching Staff 1 and
turned to walk away. As Staff 1 began following Youth A again, Youth A
4

turned and ran towards her. Staff 1 said when Youth A reached Staff 1,
she “dumped water” on Staff 1 before attempting to hit her with the
water bottle. She “dumped the whole bottle” on Staff 1 before dropping
the bottle. Staff 1 reported attempting to kick the water bottle away from
them before “tripping” over Youth A. Youth A tripped over Staff 1 and
grabbed Staff 1’s hair. Staff 1 said they both fell to the ground with
Youth A laying on top of Staff 1. Staff 1 also reported trying to get her
fingers between Youth A’s fingers so she would let loose of Staff 1’s
hair. As soon as Youth A let go, Staff 1 said she jumped up and moved
away from Youth A. At this time, Youth A began to yell to a passerby
that Staff 1 was attempting to rape her. Staff 1 reported Youth A had
ahold of her hair for approximately 25 seconds and the whole incident
beginning with the water bottle lasted approximately 2 minutes. Staff 1
denied grabbing the wrists of Youth A. She also denied telling law
enforcement she had grabbed Youth A’s wrist but that she just put her
hands close to Youth A’s wrists. The couple who were walking by the
incident stopped and Staff 1 informed them of her role at the facility and
Youth A attempting to go AWOL. Youth A had asked to use their phone
and Staff 1 informed them they should not allow this. Law Enforcement
showed up and Youth A reported Staff 1 was trying to rape her. Staff 1
reported she didn’t tell Law Enforcement that she grabbed Youth A’s
wrists but rather just put her hands near Youth A’s wrists. Law
Enforcement took both Youth A and Staff 1 back to the facility. Lead
Trainer then took Youth A to the hospital for an evaluation where Youth
A refused to be seen at the hospital. Youth A noticed a scratch on her
neck area and reported it occurred during the altercation with Staff 1.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on 1/9/2023 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth A refused to talk about the
incident or the scratch she had. She denied knowing about interactions
she has had with Staff 1 but did voice she doesn’t believe “Staff 1 did
anything wrong”.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on 1/9/2023 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported being the other
youth who went AWOL with Youth A. She remembers Staff 1 following
them until they separated, and said Staff 1 kept following Youth A. She
also reported being near the location when the incident between Staff 1
and Youth A took place. She reported Youth A grabbed Staff 1 and
Staff 1 pushed Youth A in the chest with one arm. She never observed
them on the ground and was told later by Youth A she had been
scratched and hit by Staff 1.
MDHHS Case Worker was interviewed face-to-face at the facility,
on 1/9/2023. She reported Youth A is in the process of being moved to
a more secure location. She also reported having no issues with the
4

facility at this time. She believed the facility had provided services to
Youth A.
Lead Trainer was interviewed by phone, on 1/9/2023 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported receiving a call of
Youth A and Youth B getting ready to go AWOL and she went to the
facility. She also reported trying to deescalate the youth but them
leaving anyway. She was only aware of what occurred when Staff 1
followed the youth because she overheard Staff 1 giving a report to
Law Enforcement. She denied speaking to Staff 1 about the situation
and had no concerns about Staff 1’s work with youth at the facility. She
described the AWOL policy and said staff are to follow the youth and
keep them in sight. Staff need to make sure the youth are safe if they
can follow them. Staff are to stay behind them until they lose them. The
other two staff are to stay at the facility for supervision of the other
youth. She reported staff are trained to keep distance when following
but they have no training about a bite or hair pulling release technique.
Staff 2 was interviewed by phone, on 1/9/2023 in collaboration with
MDHHS worker. He reported the incident had already occurred by the
time he arrived at the facility at 11:00 pm. He was told by Youth A that
she went to the hospital where they discovered the scratch but that she
didn’t know where the scratch came from. He also reported both Staff 1
and Youth A apologized to each other. He has never observed any
negative issues between Staff 1 and Youth A at the facility and Staff 1
is the “sweetest” person he knows. He gave a similar description of the
AWOL policy as Lead Trainer and added that staff need to keep talking
to the youth to get them to change their mind about going AWOL. One
staff should follow the youth and the other staff at the facility should call
the police. He described his training on the appropriate action if a youth
attacks a staff. He reported staff need to put their arms up to protect
themselves and “move out of the line of fire.” “Staff are not to push
them but rather just back up and get away.”
Witness was interviewed by phone, on 1/12/2023 in collaboration
with MDHHS worker. She reported observing the incident with Youth A
and Staff 1. She observed Youth A throw water at Staff 1 before
throwing the water bottle at Staff 1. The bottle bounced off Staff 1 and
then she kicked the bottle. It appeared both Staff 1 and Youth A fell to
the ground, but she didn’t see clearly “how they went to the ground”.
She also reported they were on the ground for approximately 30
seconds before getting up. Youth A began screaming at this time. She
was not close enough to observe any hair pulling or either hitting each
other. She reported calling Law Enforcement and was surprised how
quickly Law Enforcement showed up because she was still on the
phone with the operator when they showed up. Staff 1 and Youth A had
4

gotten up and started walking towards the facility when Law
Enforcement met them.
DHHS Case Manager was interviewed by phone, on 1/18/2023. She
reported Youth A is doing much better in her new placement because it
is a secure facility. She didn’t believe the prior placement was
structured to meet the needs of Youth A because she viewed it as more
of an independent living program. She also didn’t believe the program
was providing consequences to youth and received little to no support
from local Law Enforcement.
Documents Reviewed:
DHHS initial contact dated 1/3/2023. Youth A was observed to be
clean and dressed appropriately. She reported the incident involving
Staff 1 occurred on 1/2/2023. She told Staff 1 to stop following her but
when Staff 1 didn’t stop following, Youth A pulled Staff 1’s hair. Staff 1
grabbed her (no description of where the grab took place) and they just
“kept going”. Youth A also reported “they ended up on the ground” and
Staff 1 wouldn’t get off her. She was unaware of Law Enforcement
showing up at the scene.
3rd shift Checklist dated 1/1/2023. This document outlines staff’s
daily and weekly tasks along with a daily summary of the youth’s
interactions. This summary also describes any situations that have
occurred prior to the shift so oncoming staff are made aware. There is a
break down (individual summary) of each youth that includes tasks the
youth completed or did not complete, food eaten, life skills
accomplished, and medication taken or not taken. The “shift summary”
for Youth A included the following information. Youth A wanted to
discuss the incident with Staff 1 and how staff should not follow her and
the other youth. She also reported “she’ll beat any staff ass” but was
cut off by another youth telling her this was wrong. Youth A said she
was sorry to the staff. Youth A then went to bed. She was smiling and
yelling all at the same time.
Policy-Aggressive/assaultive youth, dated 3/15/2019. This
document outlines staff’s response to aggressive/assaultive youth. Staff
are to use verbal de-escalating techniques and other trauma informed
techniques with the youth. Staff need to communicate their intention to
keep them safe. Staff should encourage youth to use their safety plans
(coping skills) as part of the de-escalation. Staff need to stay at least 3
feet from the escalated youth and position themselves in an area that
they can exit from if the youth becomes assaultive. Staff are to always
maintain none-threatening body language. Staff are to offer youth an
escape route.
4

Policy-AWOLP, dated 1/2022. This document outlines staff’s actions
when a youth goes AWOL. First, staff are to follow the youth and
attempt to keep them in line-of-site. Staff are also to de-escalate the
youth and document all their efforts.
Policy-Behavior Management/Intervention dated 1/2022. This
document outlines the procedure for addressing inappropriate
behaviors. This document states, “The overall purpose of the behavior
modification/intervention policy is to assist youth in displaying behaviors
that are conductive to learning and to teach social behaviors that are
appropriate for home, school, and community settings.”
Employee schedule dated 1/1/2023. It is documented on this
schedule there are two staff working at the time of Youth A going
AWOL. The Lead Trainer is scheduled to be on call and able to
respond to situation during this time.
Policy-No touch dated 10/13/2020. This document outlines the
procedure for addressing escalated behaviors. This document states,
“staff should not touch youth at any time”. It is also stated, “staff are to
only use verbal de-escalation techniques with an escalated youth” and
“staff should always maintain 3 feet from an escalated youth”.
Policy-Violent Situations dated 3/26/2021. This document outlines
staff’s response to a violent situation with a youth. Staff are first to use
de-escalation techniques and if these fail, they need to remove
themselves and other youth from the escalated youth. They are to
ensure the safety of others and themselves. “Youth Service Specialists
should separate themselves as well as the other youth from the
aggressive youth by any means necessary to keep everyone safe.”
Staff are to keep at least 3 feet from the escalated youth and keeping
moving to keep this distance. If they are unable to deescalate the
youth, Law Enforcement should be contacted.
Policy-Verbal De-escalation Non-Restraint dated 10/13/2020. This
document outlines the procedure for addressing escalated behaviors.
This document stated, “Staff is not to handle youth physically in any
way.” Staff should encourage youth to use their coping skills and to
refer to the youth’s safety plan.
High Alert LTAI Home Safety Plan, dated 11/11/2022. This safety
plan was developed for Youth A. The first item is Youth A will be always
in line of sight. The second item is staff will encourage Youth A to use
her coping skills when she voices a desire to go AWOL. The third item
is staff must follow Youth A if she attempts to leave the facility and
4

always keep her in line of sight. Another item is that staff are to call Law
Enforcement if she leaves the facility without permission.
Let’s Talk About It Community Mental Health Services, Inc. Critical
Incident Report dated 1/1/2023. This document outlines the incident
that occurred with Youth A on 1/1/23. The incident is described and
matches the report provided by Staff 1. The interventions are identified
as de-escalation and redirection techniques being used throughout the
incident. Youth A’s reaction to the efforts to de-escalate are
documented as are Staff 1’s efforts to ensure safety and security for
Youth A. Medical treatment for Youth A is also documented and
matches the report given during interviews. The debriefing is also
documented and states, “Youth A came to Staff 1 and apologized for
putting her hands on staff and using disrespectful language”.
Trauma-Informed Care & De-escalation. There is no date on this
document and this information is provided to all staff as part of their
training. This document outlines the types of trauma, triggers, functions
of behavior, and the escalation cycle. The de-escalation phases are
listed (phase one: calm, phase two: triggers, phase three: agitation,
phase four: acceleration, and phase five: peak. The focus of this
document is to provide education and instruction on identifying and de-
escalating an agitated youth while keeping them, yourself, and other
safe. The first section is to identify the escalated youth by identifying
different behavior signs. The next section identifies several de-
escalation techniques that staff should use. One aspect is staff should
keep themselves approximately two arms lengths away from the
agitated youth. Another aspect is no touching since touch can be
misinterpreted. Verbal de-escalation is outlined and several techniques
(15) for verbal de-escalation are described in detail. Avoiding arguing
and yelling are part of the list.
Anger Management Training-Anger management: 10 tips to tame
your temper. This document has no date but is provided to all staff
during their training. Of the ten tips, it begins with “think before you
speak” and this suggests the staff take a few moments to collect their
thoughts before speaking. The second tip is calm yourself before
speaking. Staff need to state their concerns and needs clearly and
directly.
Incident/Investigation Report dated 1/3/23. This is the Law
Enforcement report for the incident between Staff 1 and Youth A, which
occurred on 1/1/2023, at 20:58. Within the narrative section of this
document it is stated, “Staff 1 did advise that during the assault she did
grab onto Youth A’s wrists in order to defend herself and trip her to the
ground”. It is later documented within the same section, “Staff 1 said
4

that she grabbed onto both of Youth A’s wrists and ended up tripping
Youth A in order for her to stop the assault”. Witness is interviewed and
her statements in this report match what she provided during her
interview.
Incident/Investigation Report Supplement Information dated
1/3/23. This is the Law Enforcement supplemental report for the
incident between Staff 1 and Youth A, which occurred on 1/1/2023, at
20:58. In the narrative section of this report, it documents the report
about the incident from Youth A. Youth A reported Staff 1 approached
her, grabbed her, and threw her to the ground. Staff 1 held her on the
ground for several seconds. Youth A also reported she grabbed Staff 1
in self-defense because she was being attacked.
Updated Treatment plan for Youth A, Date of Report: 12/29/22
Report Period: 10/30/22 through 12/29/22. This document was
developed for Youth A. It is documented that Youth A is attending
weekly therapy sessions with a focus on trauma. Her goals include
independent living skills, development of healthy social skills including
boundaries, communication, and healthy relationships, and
development of emotional regulation skills. The treatment goals appear
to meet the presenting problems that Youth A has been presenting.
Staff 1’s HR file. Documentation indicates she is up to date on all
training and there is no disciplinary action in the file.
Analysis Based upon interviews there is no evidence that supports Staff 1 acted
inappropriately when engaged in the conflict with Youth A. Evidence
suggests Staff 1 was engaged in the safety plan and AWOL procedures
while Youth A went AWOL from the facility. Evidence also indicates
Youth A attacked Staff 1 resulting in Staff 1 engaging in efforts to stop
the hair pulling by Youth A.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
It was recommended facility develop a policy to outline appropriate staff
responses when attacked (hitting, hair pulling, and biting, etc.) by youth.
This should also include training for all staff.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
4

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract and policy.
It is recommended that the current license status be continued.
1/31/2023

Paul Fatato Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
02/15/2023

Area Manager
